Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of sphinx. A Greek-type sphinx, seated upright to left on a plain rectangular plinth (her right side is largely unworked), with human female breasts thrust forward and the human head lost; part of the wings are broken away. Seemingly hand-modelled; the underneath of the plinth is very rough. Traces of a white dressing. Brown Nile silt with a grey-brown core, and abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Probably locally produced at Naukratis as fabric is similar to that used in terracottas workshop. Some doubt about whether it is hand -made, as there seems to be a mould line on the sphinx's back. Published by Winter (Winter 1903a, 230, no. 3). Whilst the Egyptian style sphinx is common throughout Late Period to Roman Period assemblages, the Greek style sphinx is apparently a rare terracotta. Winter, F. 1903. Die antiken Terrakotten III, vol.I: Die Typen der figurlichen Terrakotten. Berlin.
Appears on Gardner 1888, pl. XV, which is labelled 'Temenos of Aphrodite or Town.'
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C616)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.273) (Phase 1)
